com.qualcomm.snapdragon.sdk.gestures

Enum GestureMode

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Enum<GestureMode>
      • com.qualcomm.snapdragon.sdk.gestures.GestureMode
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Comparable<GestureMode>

    public enum GestureMode
extends java.lang.Enum<GestureMode>
    The GestureMode is a configuration value for the Gesture Device. The types of gestures and events returned are dependent on this setting.

    Multiple gesture modes are supported by the system. A given gesture mode implies a specific approach to interaction with the device. Only a single gesture mode can be active at any given time. The list of supported gesture modes is shown below. Detailed information for each gesture mode is in the detailed section of each GestureMode.

    • OFF
    • NEAR_GESTURE
    • ENGAGEMENT_GESTURE
    • POINTER
    • ENGAGEMENT_DETECTION
    • NEAR_AND_POINTER
    • NEAR_AND_ENGAGEMENT_GESTURE
    • CLICK_AND_DRAG
    • CIRCLE
    • HAND_ZOOM

    See Also:
    SwipeListener.SwipeEvent, EngagementListener.EngagementEvent, HandDetectionListener.HandDetectionEvent, CircleListener, CoverListener, HandDetectionListener

    • Enum Constant Detail

      • OFF

        public static final GestureMode OFF
        The OFF mode; gestures are disabled.

      • NEAR_GESTURE

        public static final GestureMode NEAR_GESTURE
        The NEAR Gesture mode; a SwipeEvent is generated if a listener is set.

        Near gesture is intended to work within a close range of the device. It focuses on the detection of swipe gestures in either a left or right direction. The working distance of the Near Gesture is 1-6 inches from the device.

        To perform the gesture:

        1. Start with the hand off to one side of the device.
        2. Pass the hand over the sensor in one motion.
        3. Continue until the hand is on the opposite site.
        4. If repeating the gesture, avoid passing over the sensor on the return motion.

        Demonstration of Near Gesture

        Valid Near Gesture Setups

        Near gestures may be performed in multiple setups. The device may be handheld, sitting in a cradle, or laying on a desktop surface. In general, it is strongly recommended that movement of the device itself during near gesture recognition be kept to a minimum.


        Tips for Performing Near Gestures

        Try to maintain a distance of 1 to 6 inches between the hand and the camera sensor.

        Direct the palm or the long edge of the hand toward the sensor. Avoid directing fingertips towardthe sensor.

        Attempt to keep the hand square with the device throughout the gesture.

        Near Gesture also supports the CoverListener.onCover(int, long) and CoverListener.onUncover(int, long) events.

        To perform a cover gesture:

        1. Start with the hand off to the side or away from the device.
        2. Quickly move the hand over the sensor in one motion.
        3. Hold the hand over the sensor for one second.

        Tips for Cover:

        Hold the hand within 1-3 inches of the sensor (located at the top of the device).
         

        Use palm.
        Good: 
        Bad:  

        Completely cover the sensor.
        Good: 
        Bad: 

        See Also:
        SwipeListener.SwipeEvent, CoverListener

      • ENGAGEMENT_DETECTION

        public static final GestureMode ENGAGEMENT_DETECTION
        The ENGAGEMENT only detection mode; an EngagementListener.EngagementEvent are generated if a listener is set.

        The primary purpose of the Engagement Only mode is to act as a trigger for some specific behaviour. The engagement process is identical to the process for Engagement and Gesture. In this case, however, the relevant application is intended to act upon the engagement directly as a trigger rather than awaiting a gesture.

        The intended application for this mode is a binary selection based on the engagement hand. Since engagement is possible with either the left or the right hand (and the two are distinguishable), an application may use the hand to determine a decision such as OK versus Cancel, Yes vesus No, or Continue versus Back. There is a small timeout which occurs after the initial engagement message has been sent.

        Tips for Engagement

        Ensure that the engagement distance is correct and that the hand is approximately centered within the field of view of the camera. If the hand is not completely contained within the field of view of the camera, engagement may not be recognized. Best results will be obtained by keeping the hand at a suitable distance of 1 to 4 feet from the device.

        The hand pose should keep the fingers spread apart with the hand facing the device directly.

        The hand pose should be kept square to the device. The fingers should point upward with respect to the device sensor. Avoid any in-plane or out-of-plane rotation of the hand to ensure the best possible detection of the hand engagement.

        See ENGAGEMENT_GESTURE for proper engagement technique.

      • ENGAGEMENT_GESTURE

        public static final GestureMode ENGAGEMENT_GESTURE
        The ENGAGEMENT followed by SWIPE; an EngagementEvent is generated if a listener is set, and SwipEvent is generated if a listener is set.

        Engagement and Gesture mode is intended for use at distances greater than those available to Near Gesture.

        A user interaction in Engagement and Gesture mode follows this sequence:

        1. The user engages with the device. The user will receive EngagementListener.EngagementEvent updates.
        2. The user performs one or more swipe gestures. Gestures may be repeated rapidly if they occur in the same direction. The user will receive SwipeListener.SwipeEvent updates.
        3. The user disengages from the device.

        In the first step, we refer to engaging with the device as a method of demonstrating user intent to interact with the device using gestures. Currently, the engagement method requires the user to display their open palm to the device for some short period of time (typically less than one second). Engagement distance should be within a range of 1 to 4 feet from the device. Once engaged, the gesture system will await further gestures from the user which may be used to control the device.


        Valid Gestures

        Valid gestures currently consist of swipes in four cardinal directions (Left, Right, Up, and Down). To perform a swipe, the hand should move a significant distance (at least 20 centimetres is recommended).

        Special care has been taken to support rapid gestures taking place in the same direction. For example, if the user is being shown a carousel of images, they may wish to quickly skip through some small subset of those images. In such a case, the user may rapidly swipe right multiple times in close succession. The degree of user engagement is generally displayed to the user through some sort of visual overlay shown on the device. Overlay opacity may be mapped to the degree of engagement, such that at full engagement the overlay appears completely opaque with the opacity fading to completely transparent when the user is no longer engaged with the gesture system.

        User engagement is intended to correspond to the degree of user interaction with the gesture system. Immediately after initially engaging with the system by displaying a specific hand pose, the degree of engagement should be 100%. This value will slowly tend toward zero as the user stays static or does not perform a valid gesture. Gestural interaction in this mode is only possible while the degree of engagement is greater than zero.

        Disengagement is deemed to occur when the degree of engagement reaches zero. At this point, no further gestural interaction can occur until a user re-engages with the device by performing a valid hand pose.

        Tips for Engagement and Gesture

        Ensure that the engagement distance is correct and that the hand is approximately centered within the field of view of the camera. If the hand is not completely contained within the field of view of the camera, engagement may not be recognized. Best results will be obtained by keeping the hand at a suitable distance of 1 to 4 feet from the device.

        The hand pose should keep the fingers spread apart with the hand facing the device directly.

        The hand pose should be kept square to the device. The fingers should point upward with respect to the device sensor. Avoid any in-plane or out-of-plane rotation of the hand to ensure the best possible detection of the hand engagement.

      • POINTER

        public static final GestureMode POINTER
        An ENGAGEMENT event is triggered until the engagement confidence reaches 100% when in Pointer mode; the system then handles the pointer display and clicks.

        A user interaction in Pointer mode follows this sequence:

        1. The user engages with the device with an open palm. The user will receive EngagementListener.EngagementEvent updates.
        2. The user moves their hand, maintaining the open palm pose, around the device. User may register for Hover events. The user may perform swipes and register to receive SwipeListener.SwipeEvent updates.
        3. User hovers over a location for about half a second and the system triggers a Click event.
        4. The user disengages from the device.
        The user engages the devices by moving their hand. Currently, the hand detection method requires the user to display their open palm to the device for some short period of time (typically less than one second). Hand detection distance should be within a range of 1 to 4 feet from the device. To see HoverEvents, use the Android View.OnHoverListener for Views.

        Tips for Engagement

        Ensure that the engagement distance is correct and that the hand is approximately centered within the field of view of the camera. If the hand is not completely contained within the field of view of the camera, engagement may not be recognized. Best results will be obtained by keeping the hand at a suitable distance of 1 to 4 feet from the device.

        The hand pose should keep the fingers spread apart with the hand facing the device directly.

        The hand pose should be kept square to the device. The fingers should point upward with respect to the device sensor. Avoid any in-plane or out-of-plane rotation of the hand to ensure the best possible detection of the hand engagement.

      • NEAR_AND_POINTER

        public static final GestureMode NEAR_AND_POINTER
        This is a dual mode, operating as Near and Pointer.

        If the user may use device described in NEAR_GESTURE as well as POINTER.

        This mode may be used as NEAR_GESTURE 1-6 inches from the device. This mode may also be use concurrently 1-4 feet away from the device utilizing POINTER mode.

        The user may swipe near the device and receive swipe events in NEAR GESTURE mode. They may also engage and then use the device in POINTER mode. Switching between the two modes is automatic. For swipes, the SwipeEvent's SwipeListener.SwipeEvent.swipe_type indicates whether the event was triggered from a NEAR GESTURE or from POINTER (far).

        The user may register for Swipe Events by registering GestureDeviceManager.setSwipeListener(SwipeListener). The user may register for Cover Events by registering GestureDeviceManager.setCoverListener(CoverListener). The user may register for register for hover events via the Android HoverEvent listener.

        A sample user interaction in Near and Pointer mode follows this sequence:

        1. If the user swipes near the device (1-6 inches) away to receive SwipeListener.SwipeEvent updates.
        2. If the user covers the device, they can receive CoverListener.onCover(int, long) and CoverListener.onUncover(int, long) events.
        3. The user engages with the device with an open palm 1-4 feet from the device. The user will receive EngagementListener.EngagementEvent updates. This engagement will trigger the Pointer mode.
        4. The user then moves their hand, maintaining the open palm pose, around the device. User may register for Hover events. The user may perform swipes and register to receive SwipeListener.SwipeEvent updates.
        5. User hovers over a location and the system triggers a Click event.
        6. The user disengages from the device.

        See Also:
        NEAR_GESTURE, POINTER

      • NEAR_AND_ENGAGEMENT_GESTURE

        public static final GestureMode NEAR_AND_ENGAGEMENT_GESTURE
        This is a dual mode, operating as Near and Pointer.

        If the user may use device described in NEAR_GESTURE as well as ENGAGEMENT_GESTURE.

        The user may register for Swipe Events by registering GestureDeviceManager.setSwipeListener(SwipeListener). The user may register for Cover Events by registering GestureDeviceManager.setCoverListener(CoverListener). The user may register for register for hover events via the Android HoverEvent listener.

        The user may swipe near the device and receive swipe events as in NEAR GESTURE mode. They may also engage and then use the device in ENGAGEMENT_GESTURE mode. Switching between the two modes is automatic. For swipes, the SwipeEvent's SwipeListener.SwipeEvent.swipe_type indicates whether the event was triggered from a NEAR GESTURE or from ENGAGEMENT_GESTURE (far).

        A sample user interaction in Near and Pointer mode follows this sequence:

        1. If the user swipes near the device (1-6 inches) away to receive SwipeListener.SwipeEvent updates.
        2. If the user covers the device, they can receive CoverListener.onCover(int, long) and CoverListener.onUncover(int, long) events.
        3. The user engages with the device with an open palm 1-4 feet from the devie. The user will receive EngagementListener.EngagementEvent updates. This engagement will trigger the ENGAGEMENT_GESTURE mode.
        4. The user may perform swipes and register to receive SwipeListener.SwipeEvent updates.
        5. The user disengages from the device.

        See Also:
        NEAR_GESTURE, ENGAGEMENT_GESTURE

      • CLICK_AND_DRAG

        public static final GestureMode CLICK_AND_DRAG
        This mode works similary to the POINTER mode. An ENGAGEMENT event is triggered until the engagement confidence reaches 100% when in Click and Drag mode. The system then handles the pointer display. The difference between this mode and Pointer is that a click is not triggered by hovering over a location. This mode is operated 1-4 feet from the device.

        To initiate, a system engagement using open palm is required. An ENGAGEMENT event is triggered when engagement confidence reaches 100%. EngagementListener.EngagementEvent may be received during this phase.

        The user then engages the devices by moving their hand, maintaining an open palm pose. A cursor is displayed by the system. *

        When a fist or hand puppet (closed hand) is detected, a touch down event is triggered. When the user opens their hand (open palm), a touch up event is triggered. To create a click, a user creates a fist and then releases. To drag, a user creates a fist, moves their fist, and then opens palm to release. The fist is tracked with this mode. To see HoverEvents, use the Android View.OnHoverListener for Views. See below for images.

        A sample user interaction in Click and Drag follows this sequence:

        1. The user engages with the device with an open palm 1-4 feet from the device. The user will receive EngagementListener.EngagementEvent updates. This engagement will trigger the Pointer mode.
        2. The user then moves their hand, maintaining the open palm pose, around the device. User may register for Hover events. The user may perform swipes and register to receive SwipeListener.SwipeEvent updates.
        3. User creates a over a location and the system triggers a Click Down event.
        4. User opens up their hand and creates the Open Palm pose for a Click Up event.
        5. The user disengages from the device.

        Tips for Engagement

        Ensure that the engagement distance is correct and that the hand is approximately centered within the field of view of the camera. If the hand is not completely contained within the field of view of the camera, engagement may not be recognized. Best results will be obtained by keeping the hand at a suitable distance of 1 to 4 feet from the device.

        The hand pose should keep the fingers spread apart with the hand facing the device directly.

        The hand pose should be kept square to the device. The fingers should point upward with respect to the device sensor. Avoid any in-plane or out-of-plane rotation of the hand to ensure the best possible detection of the hand engagement.

        Click:

        User performs Click in the following steps:

        1. Hold out hand with open palm to engage.
        2. Pause the hand and change the palm to a fist to simulate a mouse click down.
        3. Pause the hand and change the fist back into an open palm to simulate a mouse click up.

        Click and Drag:

        User performs a Click and Drag in the following steps:

        1. Hold out hand with open palm pose to engage.
        2. Pause the hand and change the open palm to a fist (simulate a grab).
        3. Move the hand (currently fist pose) to desired location (simulate a drag movement).
        4. Pause the hand and change the fist to an open palm (siulate a release).

        Tips:

        • The user is expected to perform the gesture in a smooth manner. It is recommended that the user does not hesitate/pause/slowdown during the gesturing. This may inadvertently trigger an immature detection and result in poor performance for fist dragging or palm following.
        • The user is expeted to perform the gesture at a reasonable speed. It is recommended that the user complete the gesture (either palm to fist or fist to palm) in no less than 1/6 of a second or no longer than 2 seconds.
        • The user is expected to perform the drag with their fist facing the camera as much as possible for better dragging performance. The following are a few fist orientations that are not desirable.
        • The user is expected to perform the gesture while the hand stays in one location. It is not recommended that user perform the gesture while the hand is visibly sliding or completely moving from one spot to another. The following are some examples:

          Sliding gesture: open palm changes to a fist while the hand is sliding downwards


          Sliding gesture: fist changes to an open palm while sliding downwards


          Running gesture: open palm changes to a fist while the hand is moving from left to right


          Running gesture: the fist changes into an open palm while the hand is moving from right to left

      • CIRCLE

        public static final GestureMode CIRCLE

        This mode tracks a circular path. It is intended for further distance, 1 to 4 feet from the device. To receive events for this mode, set the GestureDeviceManager.setCircleListener(CircleListener).

        A user interaction with Circle mode follows this sequence:

        1. The user engages with the device with an open palm. A successful engagement is when an EngagementListener.EngagementEvent.engagePercent reaches 100.
        2. The user moves their hand in one circular path. A CircleListener.OnCircle(com.qualcomm.snapdragon.sdk.gestures.CircleListener.CircleEvent) event will be triggered.
        3. The user has now initiated the circle gesture system. The user can move their hand clockwise or counterclockwise to receive CircleListener.CircleEvent updates.
        4. The user disengages from the device.

        Tips for Engagement

        Ensure that the engagement distance is correct and that the hand is approximately centered within the field of view of the camera. If the hand is not completely contained within the field of view of the camera, engagement may not be recognized. Best results will be obtained by keeping the hand at a suitable distance of 1 to 4 feet from the device.

        The hand pose should keep the fingers spread apart with the hand facing the device directly.

        The hand pose should be kept square to the device. The fingers should point upward with respect to the device sensor. Avoid any in-plane or out-of-plane rotation of the hand to ensure the best possible detection of the hand engagement.

        Tips for Circle:

        Circles are performed in Clock-Wise (CW) and Counter-Clock-Wise (CCW). A circle is performed when a hand is detected and the palm is tracked by the hand tracker. To do a circle gesture a user can simply move their hand in a circular path so that the palm draws a circle in the air. The gesture should be performed parallel to the camera sensor.

        Multiple circles can be performed consecutively. However, a user should remember that a circle is detected if the hand returns to the starting point when finishing a circle. In other words, a spiral may not result in a detected circle.

        There are no minimum and maximum distance requirements for the circles. However, the hand must be detected and the palm must be tracked all over the circle period.

        There is no requirement for the circle to be performed in the centre of screen/images. However, as mentioned above, a user should ensure that the tracker does not lose the palm while moving in a circular path. This means, the hand should be kept parallel to the camera throughout the trajectory.

        The following pictures show good hand orientations with respect to the platform.

        The following image shows a condition where the hand may be lost.

        The duration of a circle must not be less than half a second (0.5 sec) and not more than 2.5 seconds. In other words, if a circle is performed too fast, in less than 0.5 second, it will not get detected. Also, if it is performed too slow, longer than 2.5 seconds, it will not get detected either.

        A circle that is too small is ignored as it may be confusing with noisy/jittering movements of the palm centre. Diameter of a circle should be at least 1/3rd of the width of hand when it first gets detected.

        Here is a table of ranges for the speeds and distances:

        Parameter Minimum Maximum
        Duration of Circle 0.5 sec 2.5 sec
        Circle Diameter 1/3rd of hand size FOV
        Distance Hand should be detected Hand should be detected

        Set the GestureDeviceManager.setCircleListener(CircleListener) to receive CircleEvents.

      • HAND_ZOOM

        public static final GestureMode HAND_ZOOM

        This mode tracks a hand and is intended for further distance, 1 to 4 feet from the device. To receive events for this mode, set the GestureDeviceManager.setHandDetectionListener(HandDetectionListener).

        To initiate, a system engagement using open palm is required. An ENGAGEMENT event is triggered when engagement confidence reaches 100%.

        After the system is engaged, move the hand towards the device to zoom in and away from the device to zoom out. The depth of the hand is indicated as the raw z value HandDetectionListener.HandDetectionEvent.Z , ranging from 0 as hand being closest to the device to 1 as hand being furthest from the device.

        The initial z value when the hand is first engaged is provided in HandDetectionListener.HandDetectionEvent.initZ.

        The relative z value is provided in the field HandDetectionListener.HandDetectionEvent.relZ. The relative z value is a mapping of the raw z value from the range [initZ - 0.15, initZ + 0.15] to the range [0.5, 2.0].

        A user interaction with HandZoom mode follows this sequence:

        1. The user engages with the device. A successful engagement is when an EngagementListener.EngagementEvent.engagePercent reaches 100.
        2. The user moved their hand towards or away from the device. Use will receive HandDetectionListener.HandDetectionEvent updates.
        3. The user disengages from the device.

        Tips for Engagement and Zoom

        Ensure that the engagement distance is correct and that the hand is approximately centered within the field of view of the camera. If the hand is not completely contained within the field of view of the camera, engagement may not be recognized. Best results will be obtained by keeping the hand at a suitable distance of 1 to 4 feet from the device.

        After engagement, move towards or away from the device.

        The hand pose should keep the fingers spread apart with the hand facing the device directly.

        The hand pose should be kept square to the device. The fingers should point upward with respect to the device sensor. Avoid any in-plane or out-of-plane rotation of the hand to ensure the best possible detection of the hand engagement.

        GestureDeviceManager.setHandDetectionListener(HandDetectionListener) to receive HandDetectionListener.onHandDetected(HandDetectionEvent) events.

      • CIRCLE_AND_CLICK_DRAG

        public static final GestureMode CIRCLE_AND_CLICK_DRAG

        This mode a combination of Circle mode as well as Click and Drag. Refer to the mentioned modes for usage.
